questiontext.text: Internal economies of scale imply that

answer.text: a firm's average cost of production decreases the more output it produces.
a firm's average cost of production increases the more output it produces.
a firm's average cost of production stays the same as more output is produced.
a firm's average cost of production may increase or decrease the more output it produces.

questiontext.text: Internal economies of scale and product differentiation combine

answer.text: to generate some new sources of gains of trade via economic integration.
to generate some new sources of losses of trade via economic integration.
to generate some new trade barriers among countries.
to generate some new obstacles for economic growth.

questiontext.text: A perfectly competitive market is a market in which

answer.text: there are many buyers and sellers, none of whom represents a large part of the market, and firms are price takers.
there are only a few large buyers and sellers, who represent a large part of the market, and firms are price takers.
there are many buyers and sellers, none of whom represents a large part of the market, and firms are price setters.
there are only a few large firms, who represent a large part of the market, and firms are price setters.

questiontext.text: In imperfect competition,

answer.text: firms can influence the prices of their differentiated products and they are price setters.
firms can influence the prices of their differentiated products and they are price takers.
firms cannot influence the prices of their differentiated products and they are price takers.
firms cannot influence the prices of their differentiated products and they are price setters.

questiontext.text: A market in which a firm faces no competition is called
International trade based solely on internal scale economies in both countries is likely to be carried out by

answer.text: a relatively small number of imperfect competitors.
a large number of oligopolists in each country.
a relatively small number of price competing firms.
a relatively large number of price competing firms.

questiontext.text: Marginal revenue is

answer.text: the extra revenue the firm gains from selling an additional unit.
the extra utility the firm gains from selling an additional unit.
the extra cost the firm incurs from producing an additional unit.
the extra profit the firm gains from selling an additional unit.

questiontext.text: For a monopolist, the marginal revenue curve always lies below the demand curve or the marginal revenue is always less than the price because

answer.text: to sell an additional unit, the firm must lower the price of all units.
to sell an additional unit, the firm must raise the price of all units.
to sell an additional unit, the firm can keep the price of all units the same.
to sell an additional unit, the firm can lower the price of just the marginal one.

questiontext.text: A monopolistic firm

answer.text: can sell as much as it wants for any price it determines in the market.
cannot sell additional quantity unless it raises the price on each unit.
chooses an output at which marginal revenue equals marginal cost.
cannot determine the price, which is determined by consumer demand.
will always earn a profit in the long run.

questiontext.text: A monopoly firm engaged in international trade will

answer.text: equate marginal costs with the highest price the market will bear.
equate marginal costs with foreign marginal revenues.
equate marginal costs with marginal revenues in both domestic and foreign markets.
equate marginal costs with the relative world prices.

questiontext.text: A monopoly firm will maximize profits by producing where

answer.text: total revenue from domestic and foreign sales is maximized.
marginal revenue is the same in domestic and foreign markets.
prices are the same in domestic and foreign markets.
marginal revenue is higher in the domestic market.
marginal revenue is higher in foreign markets.

questiontext.text: If a firm increases its output in the ________ and unit costs ________, then the firm is experiencing ________ of scale.
If a firm increases its output in the ________ and unit costs ________, then the firm is experiencing ________ of scale.
Modeling trade in imperfectly competitive industries is problematic because

answer.text: collusion among imperfectly competitive firms makes usable data rare.
there is no single generally accepted model of behavior by imperfectly competitive firms.
it is difficult to find an imperfectly competitive firm in the real world.
there is only a single model of imperfect competition (monopoly) but imperfect competition can take many forms in the real world.
there are no models of imperfectly competitive behavior.

questiontext.text: Firms that produce ________ products must be ________ competitive.
Imperfectly competitive firms have a demand curve that ________ and a marginal revenue curve that ________ and is ________ the demand curve.

answer.text: is horizontal; is horizontal; the same as
slopes downward; slopes downward; the same as

questiontext.text: Monopolistic competition is associated with

answer.text: high profit margins in the long run.
explicit consideration at the firm level of the strategic impact of other firms' pricing decisions.

questiontext.text: If there are a large number of firms in a monopolistically competitive industry

answer.text: the country in which the firms are located can be expected to export the goods they produce.
long-run profit will be equal to zero.
there will be a small number of firms that are very large and the rest will be very small.
the firms will converge production on a standardized product.
there will be barriers to entry that prevent additional firms from entering the industry.

questiontext.text: A firm in long-run equilibrium under monopolistic competition will earn

answer.text: positive oligopoly profits because each firm sells a differentiated product.
zero economic profits because of free entry.
negative economic profits because it has economies of scale.
positive economic profit if it engages in international trade.
positive monopoly profits because each sells a differentiated product.

questiontext.text: A product is produced in a monopolistically competitive industry with scale economies. If this industry exists in two countries, and these two countries engage in trade with each other, then we would expect

answer.text: the country with a relative abundance of the factor of production in which production of the product is intensive will export this product.
the countries will trade only with other nations they are not in competition with.
the country in which the price of the product is lower will export the product.
neither country will export this product since there is no comparative advantage.
each country will export different varieties of the product to the other.

questiontext.text: If the market for products produced by firms in a monopolistically competitive industry becomes ________, then there will be ________ firms and each firm will produce ________ output and charge a ________ price.
Under oligopoly, firms' pricing policies are ________ and, under monopolistic competition, they are ________.
If a firm that uses a production process that yields economies of scale charges a price less than ________, then profit will be ________.
Under the model of monopolistic competition, a(an) ________ in the number of firms in the industry will cause ________ to ________.
Under the model of monopolistic competition, a(an) ________ in the number of firms in the industry will cause ________ charged by each firm to ________.
Under the model of monopolistic competition, a(an) ________ in the number of firms in the industry will cause ________ to ________.
When a country both exports and imports a type of commodity, the country is engaged in

answer.text: an attempt to monopolize the relevant industry.

questiontext.text: The monopolistic competition model can be used to show the following EXCEPT

answer.text: how trade limits the size of the national market and the variety of goods available to domestic consumers.
how trade improves the trade-off between scale and variety that individual nation face.
how trade creates a world market larger than any of the national markets that comprise it.
how a larger market leads to both a lower average price and the availability of a greater variety of goods.

questiontext.text: In larger markets there will be both more firms and more sales per firm,

answer.text: consumers in a large market will be offered both lower prices and a greater variety of products than consumers in small markets.
consumers in a small market will be offered both lower prices and a greater variety of products than consumers in large markets.
consumers in a large market will be offered both higher prices and a very limited variety of products than consumers in small markets.
consumers in a small market will be offered the same prices and same variety of products as consumers in small markets.

questiontext.text: If the market for products produced by firms in a monopolistically competitive industry becomes ________, then there will be ________ firms and each firm will produce ________ output and charge a ________ price.
International trade based on external scale economies in both countries is likely to be carried out by

answer.text: a large number of oligopolists in each country.
a relatively large number of price competing firms.
a relatively small number of price competing firms.
a relatively small number of imperfect competitors.

questiontext.text: Product differentiation and internal economies of scale lead to

answer.text: trade between similar countries with no comparative advantage differences between them.
no trade between similar countries with no comparative advantage differences between them.
a smaller variety of goods available to consumers.
higher price that consumers have to pay.

questiontext.text: The integrated market supports ________ firms, each producing at a ________ scale and selling at a ________ price than either national market does on its own.
An industry is characterized by scale economies, and exists in two countries. Should these two countries engage in trade such that the combined market is supplied by one country's industry, then

answer.text: consumers in both countries would have more varieties and lower prices.
consumers in both countries would have higher prices and fewer varieties.
consumers in the exporting country only would have higher prices and fewer varieties.
consumers in both countries would have fewer varieties at lower prices.
consumers in the importing country only would have higher prices and fewer varieties.

questiontext.text: In the integrated market after trade, both Home and Foreign consumers

answer.text: benefit from a greater variety of goods at a lower price.
suffer from fewer variety of goods at a higher price.
suffer from fewer quality of goods at a higher price.
benefit from higher quality of goods at a higher price.

questiontext.text: An industry is characterized by scale economies and exists in two countries. In order for consumers of its products to enjoy both lower prices and more variety of choice

answer.text: the two countries must engage in international trade with each other.
each country's marginal cost must equal that of the other country.
the monopoly must lower prices in order to sell more.
they must combine to become a multinational corporation.
the marginal cost of this industry must equal marginal revenue in the other.

questiontext.text: In an industry where firms experience internal scale economies, the long-run cost of production will depend on

answer.text: whether the country engages in intra-industry trade.
whether the country engages in inter-industry trade.

questiontext.text: The simultaneous export and import of widgets by the United States is an example of

answer.text: the effect of a monopoly on international trade.

questiontext.text: Intra-industry trade is a very important component of trade for the United States in many different industries EXCEPT
Intra-industry trade plays an even more prominent role in the trade of

answer.text: labor-intensive goods among less advanced industrial nations.
agricultural goods among less advanced industrial nations.

questiontext.text: The gains from integration generated by economies of scale were most pronounced for

answer.text: the developing countries of Asia and Africa.
China and not the rest of the world.

questiontext.text: Intra-industry trade is most common in the trade patterns of

answer.text: the developing countries of Asia and Africa.
China with the rest of the world.

questiontext.text: Before 1965, tariff protection by Canada and the United States produced a Canadian auto industry

answer.text: that was largely self-sufficient, neither importing nor exporting much.
that was completely dependent on the U.S. auto industry.

questiontext.text: After the free trade agreement in 1964,

answer.text: Canada's auto imports and exports both increased sharply.
Canada's auto imports increased and exports decreased.
Canada's auto exports increased and imports decreased.
Canada's auto imports and exports both decreased sharply.

questiontext.text: With the implementation of NAFTA, the transformation of the auto industry with substantial productivity gain expanded to
The dismantling of NAFTA

answer.text: hit Mexico and Canada's automotive production the hardest.
led to higher car production in the United States.
decrease in car production outside North America.
decreased in price of cars produced outside North America.

questiontext.text: Trade (or economic integration)

answer.text: led to an increase in competition between firms.
led to a decrease in competition between firms.
may or may not affect competition between firms.

questiontext.text: Increased competition from trade (or economic integration) tends to

answer.text: force the worst-performing firms to exit the market.
force the best performing firms to exit the market.
provide fewer sales opportunities in new markets for surviving firms.
provide more incentives for new firms to join the market.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true?Compared to a firm with a higher marginal cost, a firm with a lower marginal cost will

answer.text: set a lower price but at a higher markup over marginal cost.

questiontext.text: In the model of monopolistic competition, if firms have ________ average cost curves, then opening trade will ________ the total number of firms and ________ the average price.
In the model of monopolistic competition, if firms have ________ average cost curves, then opening trade will cause ________ firms to ________ the industry.

In the model of monopolistic competition, compared to a firm with a higher marginal cost, a firm with a lower marginal cost will set a ________ price, produce ________ output, and earn ________ profits.

In the model of monopolistic competition, compared to a firm with a lower marginal cost, a firm with a higher marginal cost will set a ________ price, produce ________ output, and earn ________ profits.

In the model of monopolistic competition, an increase in industry output will cause individual firms' demand curves to become ________, which will ________ demand for higher-priced goods and ________ demand for lower-priced goods.
In the model of monopolistic competition, an increase in industry output will ________ producers of higher-priced goods and ________ producers of lower-priced goods.

In the model of monopolistic competition, an increase in industry output will ________ market shares and ________ profits of producers of higher-priced goods and will ________ market shares and ________ profits of producers of lower-priced goods.
In the model of monopolistic competition, trade costs

answer.text: explain why some firms choose not to export.
explain why some firms choose to import.
associated with national borders increase trade among countries.

questiontext.text: In the model of monopolistic competition, trade costs between countries will cause domestic and foreign markets to have ________ prices, ________ quantities sold, and ________ profit levels.
In the model of monopolistic competition, trade costs between countries cause

answer.text: marginal costs of exported goods to exceed the marginal costs of goods sold domestically.
all firms that can earn a profit on domestic sales to export their goods at higher prices.
countries to negotiate the elimination of trade costs by mutual subsidization of trade.
marginal costs of goods sold domestically to exceed the marginal costs of exported goods.
all firms that can earn a profit on domestic sales to export their goods at lower prices.

questiontext.text: In the model of monopolistic competition, trade costs between countries cause

answer.text: marginal costs of goods sold domestically to exceed the marginal costs of exported goods.
countries to negotiate the elimination of trade costs by mutual subsidization of trade.
prices of goods sold domestically to exceed the prices of exported goods.
some firms that can earn a profit on domestic sales to refrain from exporting their goods.
all firms that can earn a profit on domestic sales to export their goods at higher prices.

questiontext.text: Trade costs affect the following EXCEPT

answer.text: how a firms will let go of profit for the benefit of domestic and overseas customers.
how a firm responds to competition in a market.
whether a firm will export their products.
how much a firm will lower its markup for the export market.

questiontext.text: In response to trade costs,

answer.text: a firm with a higher marginal cost will choose to set a lower markup over marginal cost for the export market.
a firm with a lower marginal cost will choose to set a lower markup over marginal cost for the export market.
a firm with a higher marginal cost will choose to set a higher markup over marginal cost for the export market.
a firm with a lower marginal cost will not export to the foreign market.

questiontext.text: The trade practice when a firm sets an export price lower than its domestic price is called
Any firm from Foreign can appeal to its local authorities and seek punitive damages against the unfair trade practice of dumping in the form of
Economists believe that

answer.text: there is no good economic justification for dumping to be considered particularly harmful.
dumping is not a controversial issue in trade policy.
trade costs have no impact on firms' pricing decisions in the export market.

questiontext.text: Complaints are often made to the International Trade Commission concerning foreign "dumping" practices. These complaints typically claim that

answer.text: foreign companies are charging prices that are lower than prices they charge countries other than the U.S.
foreign companies are charging exorbitant prices that are higher than the true value of the products.
U.S. consumers cannot differentiate between the foreign and domestic goods.
U.S. firms are harmed by the unfair pricing of foreign exporters.
U.S. consumers are harmed by the lack of quality control or health concerns in foreign countries.

questiontext.text: Most antidumping complaints were directed at ________ in the early 1990s, at ________ since 1995.
Antidumping laws

answer.text: allow domestic firms to be protected from foreign competition by raising their competitors' costs.
allow foreign firms to easily enter the domestic market.
allows domestic firms to be protected from foreign competition by lowering their competitors' costs.
allows foreign firms to be more competitive in the domestic market.

questiontext.text: When U.S. tire manufacturers successfully lobbied for antidumping duties on Chinese tires in 2009,

answer.text: production shifted to South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, and exports from those countries doubled.
tire imports from China continued to increase.
tire exports from China and all other countries to the U.S. decreased.
tire exports from U.S. tire manufacturers increased.

questiontext.text: In 2012, after Whirlpool won its antidumping case against the imports of washing machines produced by LG and Samsung in South Korea, LG and Samsung

answer.text: shifted their washing machine production for the U.S. market to China.
shifted their washing machine production for the U.S. market to Vietnam and Thailand.
shifted their washing machine production for the U.S. market to the U.S.
shifted their washing machine production for the U.S. market to Canada and Mexico.

questiontext.text: A corporation is considered a multinational ________ if ________.

answer.text: parent; more than 10% of its stock is held by a foreign company
child; more than 50% of its stock is held by a foreign company
monopolist; it owns more than 50% of a foreign firm
parent; it owns more than 10% of a foreign firm
child; more than 10% of its stock is held by a foreign company

questiontext.text: A corporation is considered a multinational ________ if ________.

answer.text: child; more than 50% of its stock is held by a foreign company
child; more than 10% of its stock is held by a foreign company
parent; more than 10% of its stock is held by a foreign company
affiliate; more than 10% of its stock is held by a foreign company
monopolist; it owns more than 50% of a foreign firm

questiontext.text: Consider the following two cases. In the first, a U.S. firm purchases 18% of a foreign firm. In the second, a U.S. firm builds a new production facility in a foreign country. Both are ________, with the first referred to as ________ and the second as ________.
When a multinational affiliate replicates production in a foreign country it is called ________ foreign direct investment.
When a multinational affiliate replicates elements of a production process in a foreign country it is called ________ foreign direct investment.
Vertical FDI is mainly driven by
In vertical FDI, when a multinational ships intermediate goods across its network of domestic and foreign affiliates, the resulting trade is classified as
Horizontal FDI is mainly driven by
Toyota's replicating the production for its most popular car model, the Corolla, in assembly plants in many countries all over the world is an example of
A firm's foreign direct investment decisions are, in the case of horizontal FDI, strongly influenced by ________ and, in the case of vertical FDI, strongly influenced by ________.
Fluctuations in FDI flows are strongly influenced by the following factors EXCEPT

answer.text: the ups and downs of the domestic business cycles.
the waves of cross-border mergers and acquisitions.

questiontext.text: Historically, ________ have been the biggest recipients of inward FDI.
From 2017 to 2019, FDI outflows are dominated by
A firm is more likely to engage in horizontal foreign direct investment if

answer.text: trade costs are low and firms experience constant returns to scale in production.
trade costs are low and there are increasing returns to scale in production.
trade costs are high and there are increasing returns to scale in production.
trade costs are high and there are decreasing returns to scale in production.
trade costs are low and there are decreasing returns to scale in production.

questiontext.text: The proximity-concentration trade-off for FDI happens when

answer.text: firms have an incentive to locate a production facility near their foreign customers to avoid the high trade costs associated with exports to that foreign destination.
trade costs are low and exporting is less expensive.
it is cost effective to replicate the production process many times.
firms operate facilities that produce too little output to take advantage of increasing returns to scale in production.

questiontext.text: If the total trade-related cost to export exceeds the alternative of the fixed cost of setting up an additional production facility in the foreign market, then

answer.text: exporting is more expensive and FDI is the profit-maximizing choice.
FDI alternative is more expensive, and exporting is the profit-maximizing choice.
there should be no trade between the two countries.
neither exporting nor FDI is the profit-maximizing choice.

questiontext.text: Higher trade costs on one hand and lower fixed production costs on the other hand

answer.text: have no impact on the FDI cutoff.

questiontext.text: A firm's decision to break up its production chain and move parts of that chain to a foreign supplier is called
Foreign outsourcing is

answer.text: the transfer of operations to foreign contractors.
the substitution of immigration for foreign direct investment.

questiontext.text: During the past decade, U.S. imports of business services have ________, U.S. exports of business services have ________, and U.S. net exports of business services have ________.
A scale cutoff for foreign sourcing depends on

answer.text: the production cost differentials and the fixed cost of coordinating with a foreign supplier.
the corporate tax rates and government subsidies.
the number of jobs to be created in the foreign market.

questiontext.text: When the scale effect is strong,

answer.text: the decisions to use some foreign suppliers make the firm more likely to use others.
the decisions to use some foreign suppliers will have no impact on whether the firm will use others.
the decisions to use some no foreign suppliers will never change.
the decisions to use some foreign suppliers will make the firm less likely to use others.

questiontext.text: U.S. firms that source from a wider range of countries

answer.text: enjoy greater cost advantages and have higher scales of production.
enjoy smaller cost advantages and have lower scales of production.
incur higher fixed costs and bear higher risks.
incur higher tax rates and bear higher risks.

questiontext.text: Sourcing choices are based on different trade-offs between

answer.text: cost savings and the fixed costs of coordinating with suppliers in foreign destinations.

questiontext.text: In terms of foreign sourcing, China and Mexico offer ________ cost savings with relatively ________ fixed costs while Germany and Canada offer substantially ________ fixed costs.
As a substitute for horizontal FDI,

answer.text: a parent could license an independent firm to produce and sell its products in a foreign location.
a parent could contract an independent firm to perform a specific part of the production process in a foreign location.
a parent could build more manufacturing facilities in their home country.
a parent could expand the current manufacturing facilities in their home country.

questiontext.text: As a substitute for vertical FDI,

answer.text: a parent could contract with an independent firm to perform specific parts of the production process in a foreign location.
a parent could license an independent firm to produce and sell its products in a foreign location.
a parent could contract with more independent suppliers in their home country.
a parent could expand the current manufacturing facilities in their home country.

questiontext.text: A firm selects a make-or buy internationalization choice by considering the following EXCEPT

answer.text: the difference between the unemployment rates at home and abroad.
the different trade-offs between production cost savings and the fixed cost of moving parts of the production process abroad.
the risks of losing some proprietary technology during licensing.
the potential arising conflict regarding specific attributes of the inputs that cannot be specified in a legal contract between the buying and supplying firms.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true?In a world where production chains increasingly stretch around the world, the rise of intermediate good trade

answer.text: makes measures of bilateral trade deficits based on standard trade flows (at gross value) still irrelevant.
makes measures of bilateral trade deficits based on standard trade flows (at gross value) irrelevant.
affects the measures of the bilateral trade deficit across various U.S. trading partners.

questiontext.text: The reported U.S. iPhone imports from China

answer.text: represent imports from many other countriesincluding the United Statesthat export iPhone components to China.
represent manufacturing costs with components produced solely in China.
represent value of iPhone components exported to China from the U.S. only.
represent only the value added of assembly, testing cost, and battery produced in China.

questiontext.text: When a firm switches from domestic sourcing to foreign sourcing, it is commonly referred to as
In many cases, the overall employment effect for the offshoring firm is positive because

answer.text: firms expand their overseas employment as well as U.S. employment thanks to higher productivity.
jobs used to be performed in the U.S. are now moved overseas.
call center or manufacturing workers displaced by offshoring are not the ones being hired by the expanding firms.
U.S. service offshoring has grown faster than inshoring (exports of business services).

questiontext.text: Manufacturing employment has been steadily decreasing over the past 30 years in the US,

answer.text: but offshoring played a very minor role in this trend.
and offshoring played a very significant role in this trend.
but offshoring has nothing to do with this trend.
and offshoring is the main reason for this trend.

questiontext.text: As with other forms of trade, trade in intermediates has substantial consequences for
During the past decade, U.S. imports of business services have ________, U.S. exports of business services have ________, and U.S. net exports of business services have ________.
